newsitem.title: JAPAN: JGBs end Tokyo firmer but looking for direction.
newsitem.headline: JGBs end Tokyo firmer but looking for direction.

text.p: Japanese government bond (JGB) futures ended Tokyo trade firmer on Monday but found their topside limited. They fell back from a brief foray as high as 127.05 sales and sales subsequently lined up above 127.00, traders said.
But dips were expected to be similarly limited amid an absence of fresh selling factors and technical support near 126.90 seen holding steady.
The benchmark 10-year September JGB futures contract closed at 126.95, up from 126.83 at Friday's close, with turnover of 27,094 contracts. It ranged from 126.84 to 127.05.
The market was watching moves in Tokyo stocks, which ended the day lower on negative influence from Friday's fall on Wall Street, but traders said the impact was limited.
Although the key Nikkei-225 index at one point fell as low as 18,835.48, it managed to hold above a low of 18,801.68 marked last Wednesday and finished at 19,041.10, still down by 284.93 from Friday.

But bond buying was inhibited by concerns about possible profit-taking sales to offset these losses ahead of half-year book-closings at the end of September, and so the weakness had little impact, traders said.
One trader said, however, that if the Nikkei manages to stay at 18,000 or above by end-September, such profit-taking sales are likely to be limited.
"Right now the market needs more signs of fundamental economic weakness to help push it higher; stocks alone won't do it," he added.

A lack of activity from investors, whose market participation still appears to be thinned by summer vacations, prevented follow-through buying after key September rose on early bids and was one of the reasons behind the market's generally lethargic moves, traders said.
The yield on the benchmark 182nd 10-year cash bond stood at 2.085 percent at 0636 GMT against 2.090 percent at Friday's Tokyo close.

Traders said the topside was being weighted slightly by this week's expected issue of a number of corporate bonds, but that the impact would be more psychological than anything else as the volume is unlikely to be that large.
"Of course, the market will watch to see how these are absorbed. But it is unlikely to become a big concern," one trust bank trader said. --Elaine Lies +81-3-3432-8806
